div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 4 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
ADVERTISEMENTS and SUBSCRIPTIONS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C.
Cairo Offices.-No. 1 Sharia Vervudachi, (opposite the Agricultural Bank.)

div.head: BOVRIL
div.p: BOVRIL est le produit garanti du meilleur bétail qui existe.
C'est un repas à la minute qui protège contre les intempéries.
"BOVRIL" et "Bonne Cuisine" sont deux mots qui disent la même chose.

BOVRIL répond a une nécessité; il est non seulement une boisson delicieuse et saine, mais il est encore indispensable pour préparer instantanement des soupes et sauces appétisantes. Bovril n'a pas de rival pour corser les plats les plus récherches.
A further credit of IE 2,711 has been granted for the completion of the Sanganib lighthouse in the Red Sea.
The Government has taken over two river vachts, specially built by Messrs. Thos. Cook & Sons, for the use of the Public Works and Financial Advisers.
Mr. Bandmann's Company "The Follies," will definitely open at the Abbas Theatre, Cairo, On Monday next for one week. This popular company is arriving in Egypt on Sunday next.
During the month of June the Repression of Slave Trade Department liberated 7 Sudanese 4 in Alexandria, 1 at Dakalieh and 2 in Cairo. Two Abyssinians were also freed in Cairo.

The offices of the Nile Cold Storage Company at Boulac were entered by burglars during Sunday night, and a sum of £33 was stolen from the safe. The police have been informed and have the matter in hand.

The sentence of one year's imprisonment, which was recently passed upon Soliman Eff. Fahmy, for having destroyed certain commercial documents to the detriment of Salah Eddine Bey Sherif, was yesterday reduced in the Native Court of Appeal, Cairo, to six months' imprisonment and a fine of L.E. 100., legal costs also to be paid by him.

A duel took place at Abbassia on Monday evening, between Mr. Rudy, of the "Egyptian Standard," and Nachat Bey, author of an article in the "Progres" which the former considered to be of an offensive nature. Pistols were the weapons selected and two shots were exchanged, without any injury being done. Honour satisfied!

A detachment of special police raided a tobacco store belonging to a certain Yacob Karabet and two others, where they discovered. a large quantity of hashish. The owners were arrested and, despite their protestation that they are American naturalised subjects, will be tried according to Egyptian law, as their case comes under the new law relating to naturalised subjects resident in a foreign country for more than three years.

A grand family ball is to be held on Saturday the 10th inst., by the International Typografic League at the Petrou Casino, Khedivah Station, Ramleh, for the benefit of the funds of the league. The ball will commence at 9 p.m. and the band of the Jewish Philarmonic Society under the direction of Professor B. Leporati and the orchestra under the direction of Professor S. Grasso will be in attendance.

During the week ending the 29th instant, 29 cases of bubonic plague were registered throughout Egypt, of which 6 occurred at Alexandria, 2 at Port Said, 3 at Beba, 11 at Damanhour and 7 at Nag-Hamadi. From the beginning of the year until 29th instant, 1,028 cases of plague were registered as against 395 cases recorded during the corresponding period of last year. One recovery was reported from Beba during the past 24 hours. 22 patients are still under treatment.

During 1906, 5,067 persons visited the Alexandria Museum, the number during 1905 being 2,896. March and April were the busiest months of the year, the numbers of visitors being 692 and 523, respectively. In January In January there were 499 visitors, in May 422, and in December 412. The lowest number of visitors was recorded in November, in which month there were only 269. The total receipts for the year from the museum were L.E. 78,990.

Considerable consternation was caused among the inhabitants of the Mousky on Monday night by a gang of French Jewish hooligans, who, armed with knives and sticks, stationed themselves in the street and molested the passers-by. The mamour of the Ganmalieh kism was called out to capture the hooligans and this was affected by a considerable body of police. The men were handed over to the French consular authorities, and it is said that the Government intend to demand their expulsion from the country as dangerous characters.

The Postmaster General was recently asked a question in the House of Commons on the subject of the comparative value of the Suez Canal route and other mail routes to the East. In his reply he said: "The approximate time of transit from London to Shanghai by the different routes available for the conveyance of mails is as follows: viâ Siberia, 20 days; via Vancouver, 27 or 28 days according to the season; viâ Suez, 30-35 days; via the United States of America, 42-45 days. The cost per pound of the conveyance of letters sent from England to Shanghai viâ Siberia is estimated at 6s. 8d. For letters sent via Suez by French Packet, the cost is estimated at 4s. 3d., and in the case of German Packets at 4s. 10d. per pound. I am not in a position to give similar information in regard to letters sent viâ Vancouver or by British Packet viâ Suez, as both the Packet Companies concerned receive a round subsidy covering the whole of the services performed by them.”

div.head: CROMER'S GRANT VOTED.
div.p: In the House of Commons the grant to Lord Cromer of £50,000 was passed by the substantial majority of 147. The Premier, Mr. Balfour, and Sir E. Grey united in a well-deserved eulogy to Lord Cromer for his services. Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman said that of all the peaceful administrators through-out the Empire to-day Lord Cromer was the foremost in courage, wisdom, resource, and patience.
Mr. Redmond's baldersdash clearly irritated the members and only brought contempt on himself and his cause.
Lord Ripon and Lord Landsdowne in the House of Lords paid splendid testimony to Lord Cromer's services and the vote was passed unanimously.

House of Commons. The House voted the grant of £50,000 to Lord Cromer by 254 votes to 107 after a heated debate, the Nationalist and Labourite members attacking Lord Cromer, especially in connection with the Denishwai incident. Sir E. Grey spiritedly defended Lord Cromer's action. Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman proposed the grant and Mr. Baltour seconded it in eulogistic speeches. Mr. William Redmond denied that Lord Cromer was entitled to an unprecedentedly enormous som. The grant was inconsistent with the Liberal principle in view of the prevalent distress. Lord Cromer had benefited Egyptian finance which therefore should bear the cost.
Mr. Grayson, in a maiden speech, said that the Government's mandate was to solve the ghastly social problems and not to provide high-salaried officials with grants.

Sir E. Grey admitted that such grants were rare, but not rarer than Lord Cromer's services. Referring to Mr. Redmond's remarks regarding Denishwai, Sir E. Grey said that Lord Cromer, like himselt, considered that the judges were prompted by every desire to secure justice. This was not the time to review the sentences passed in connection with that incident. It was impossible to measure Lord Cromer's services by cash: his expenses had exceeded his salary. The Government preferred, instead of an Ambassador's pension, to grant him a lump sum as a special recognition on a very special occasion.
Mr. John Robertson condemned the Denshwai procedure, but he did not think that the case against Lord Cromer was such as to give clear ground for objecting to the grant.
House of Lords. The House unanimously concurred with the House of Commons regarding the grant to Lord Cromer, after warm eulogies by Lords Ripon and Lansdowne.

div.head: FINANCIAL CRISIS.
div.p: The following applications for the benefit of the "concordat preventif" have been made at the Alexandria Mixed Courts during June and July:--
Mohamed Sembel and his son Tewfik.

div.head: PUBLIC DEBT COMMISSION.
div.p: Mr. Olarovsky, the newly appointed Russian representative on the Public Debt Commission in succession to Mr. Von Hoeltzke, is probably arriving in Egypt at the end of August from Russia. Mr. Olarovsky was formerly in the Diplomatic Service at Bangkok where he was stationed for seven years. Prior to that he was Consul General at New York and San Francisco and also in Japan and China. He is married to an American lady. He speaks English perfectly and is a keen sportsman. He was the founder of the Bangkok Sporting Club where he kept a racing stable. Last year he met with a serious. automobile accident in Siam and had to have his leg amputated. He and his wife were very popular in Siam and will be welcome additions to Cairo society.
Mr. Olarovsky is a friend of Colonel Savage, the American novelist, the author of "My Official Wife," He figures as the hero of another of Savage's novels "The Mystery of a Shipyard.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Ellerman liner "Avon" sailed from Malta last evening and is due here with a general cargo next Saturday morning.
The SS. "Persian Prince" left Malta yesterday and is due to arrive at Alexandria on Saturday.

div.head: BIG PROPERTY DEAL.
div.p: The Société Agricole de Kafr Dawar, which was recently formed in Belgium with sixteen million francs capital, has purchased from the Dranet Pasha Daira and Mrs. Zervudachi a fine estate of 9,593 feddans in the neighbourhood of Kafr-Dawar. The price was L E. 907,201. A portion of the purchase money was paid cash down and the rest in mortgage debentures up to L.E. 462,900. The price per feddan comes to LE. 94.569 min. This is an excellent price for the deal comprises the big market at Kafr Dawar, which is open once a week, the ginning factory and other buildings at El Ackrisha, the pumping installations, steam ploughs, and the cattle on the estates.

The following companies took part in the foundation of the Société Agricole de Kafr Dawar and keep a financial interest in it: Société Agricole et Industrielle d'Egypte, Compagnie Immobilière d'Egypte, Compagnie Agricole du Nil, Egyptian Entreprise and Development Company, and the Gharbieh Land Company.
The estate, which has just been purchased covers five villages: Zimani Bardallah, Wastanieh, Ackrisha, Garragha, and Boulin.

This transaction is a very significant illustration of the great confidence which Egypt inspires in European capitalists despite the existing acute financial crisis, the purchase price of the estate being not far short of a million pounds.

div.head: BOURSE AND BANKING COMPANY.
div.p: It is curious that nothing further has been done in regard to the Board of Directors of the Bourse and Banking Company coming to an arrangement with the object of giving satisfaction to their shareholders. If the Board is under the impression that things are to be allowed to remain in the present unfortunate position, we are afraid they are labouring under a misapprehension, as we understand that it is the intention of a group of shareholders to take collective action with the object of ascertaining how far the members of the board can be held responsible for taking upon them- selves the right to refuse delivery of the shares. When share holders were invited to subscribe to this company last February, the management called up the whole of the capital at once and undertook in exchange to furnish the shares in due course. If there has been mismanagement with the funds of the concern this is not a valid or justifiable reason for witholding the shares.

div.head: THE YEMEN SITUATION.
div.p: Some 800 Turkish troops left Rudda recently to reinforce the troops at Nadhira and other places. They were met by the rebels. in Sailut-Hama, a valley between two mountains, near Yerim, when the rebels attacked the Imperial troops, killing about 200. The rest of the troops fled to Yerim.

The rebels have been disloged by the Turks from As-Sudda valley after severe fighting, in which about 500 of the Turks were killed, and about 200 among the rebels. The rebels are reported to be holding commanding positions. Moakhil Sanani, an Arab Turkish ruler in Ebb, a district near Yerim, was murdered by the rebels near the gate of Ebb for treacherous conduct towards them. Last year when the rebels occupied Ebb he acted treacherously towards them by allowing the Turks to enter the town and dislodge the rebels.

Consequent upon the death of the Mufti of Zaheed, trouble has arisen among the Arab soldiers at Zaheed and about eight casualties. have occurred. The soldiers belong to the different tribes, and are now divided into two factions.
The monsoon rains this year in Yemen have been much heavier than was expected and far exceed the rains they have had for several years past. It has extended throughout the greater part of the Yemen

The Mutasarit of Taez arrived here with some Arab followers and left by the mail steamer. The Kaimakam of Kataba also passd here en route to Constantinople. Rumour says that these officials are called to Constantinople in connection with a complaint made by the native representatives against then.

div.head: ESBEKIEH GARDENS.
div.p: The band of the Kings Own Scottish Borderers will play the following programme of music (by kind permission of Colonel D.A. Macfarlane D.S.O. and Officers, in the Esbekieh Gardens, Cairo, to-morrow from 9 to 11 o'clock.
Valse-Sizilietta-Blon. Galop-Champagne-Schirbel. Regimental March - Khedivial Hymn.

div.head: BRITISH CONSULAR COURT.
div.p: Many circumstances point to the fact that the British colony in Egypt is at last becoming awake to the necessity of action in a matter with which its interests are closely connected. Recently there has been some discussion in our columns on the fact that only 29 members of the British colony at Alexandria showed sufficient interest in the question of Lord Cromer's memorial to answer Mr. R. J. Moss's circular on that subject, although no less than a thousand circulars were sent out. A correspondent suggested that one of the reasons which may have induced this remarkable display of slackness may have been the manner in which the interests of the colony were neglected by Lord Cromer for the sake of "la hante politique" and he specially instanced the abolition of the British Court here as it existed in the days of Sir Charles Cookson, inasmuch as that Court was abolished as a principal court and reduced to the status of a provincial Court because its existence supported the theory of the capitulations, which were obnoxious to his Lordship. Since the publication of that letter we have received others in support of the principle laid down therein. In fact, the anomaly referred to by our correspondent, and generally the chaotic state of the system (or rather want of system) upon which the jurisdiction of the British Consular Courts is exercised in this country, have long ago forced themselves upon the attention of those whose daily occupation brings them into touch with the working side of the Consular Courts, and we believe that in the early part of the year 1906 a move was made with a view to bringing about an improvement. A gentleman who has now retired from Egypt, whose name need not now be mentioned, felt so strongly upon this matter that, even after his retirement, he pressed the question upon the attention of the authorities by repeated calls at Downing Street. Simultaneously the Judges of the Supreme Consular Court were un officially approached; and neither on their side, nor at the Foreign Office, was there any opposition in principle, it being recognised that "something ought to be done." The Judges, we believe, fully recognise the strength of the grievance, but obviously they could not make any move in the matter. It was suggested that a memorial to the Foreign Office might have the desired effect. This idea however, was dropped, it having been unofficially ascertained that such a move would be "distasteful in high quarters." Of course as soon as this fact became known the promoters of this much needed reform had perforce to abandon any further efforts for it was foolish to contest the principle of "Mea voluntas suprema lex." Now that this objection is removed, there is every reason to begin agitating again for this much needed step, especially in view of the recent enormous increase of English compaines in Egypt. There can be no suggestion that the carrying out of this reform is hampered by "complicated legislative machinery." In our opinion the change could be carried through by a stroke of the pen. Read Article 14 of the principal Order in Council under which the consular jurisdiction is exercised:"The Supreme Court-(meaning the Chief Judge and the Assistant Judge)-- shall ordinarily sit in Constantinople and as occasion requires at Alexandria and Cairo ; but may on emergency sit at any other place in the Ottoman Dominions, and may at any time transfer its ordinary sittings to any such place as the Secretary of State approves. Under this Article the Judges may sit at the same time at different places, and each such sitting shall be deemed to be a sitting of the Supreme Court." It seems obvious that in order to effect the reform now so much needed, all that is required is that the Secretary of State should, under this Article, give directions that one of the Judges of the Supreme Court shall take up his permanent residence in Alexandria. This would in no way interfere with the other Judge, who would continue to hold his Court in Constantinople.

The difficulties in the way of this important and very desirable reform are not in any wise legislative, but purely "administrative", which means political; subordinate, that is to say, to what our correspondent has dignified with the name of "la haute politique". So long as the "Capitulations" do exist (and we have never defended these latter day anomalies) there is no reason based upon fairness or political wisdom, why British subjects should be placed at a disadvantage as coinpared with the other nationalities settled in Egypt. Indeed we may be permitted to doubt whether it is really sound "politique" to let these other nationalities see how the powers that be can unhesitatingly sacrifice the interests of those now directly within their grasp when political necessity demands.

div.head: I'M NOT
div.p: I went to have my morning dip.
We dived: Whilst in the air, he cried
I breakfasted, then sought the train,
At night I strolled into the Club,
Played bridge, and quaffed some beer;

div.head: MUNICIPALITY REPORT
div.p: Appended to the report of Chataway Bey on the work of the Municipality of Alexandria during 1906 is a chapter by Breccia Bey on the t Museum department, which is well deserving of attention.

CHATBY NECROPOLIS. During last year ( excavations were continued at Chatby and the results were as equally fruitful as the first year's excavations. The discoveries included several painted stele, many of which bore Greek inscriptions giving the name, the patronymical name, and sometimes the country of the deceased; hydriform or amphoriform cinerary urns; cups; vases of many kinds, including painted ones of a fine black metallic colour with decorations in white, red, and gold yellow. These vases are analogous with those inaccura tely described as "Gnathia" or "Fasano" and which are believed to originate from Tarento. The number which has been found on this site, even after the spoilations to which Alexandria has been a victim, affords the supposition that the origin of these vases should be sought in the Hellenic East. Among other discoveries were a beautiful ivory flute, funeral crowns or palms in gilded bronze, plaster, or painted earthenware, and other small objects of industrial interest."

POMPEY'S PILLAR.-The excavations in the environment of Pompey's Pillar which produced so much of interest in 1905, revealed two sphinxes of Assouan granite almost intact, the measurements of which were 4 metres long and 2 metres high. A third, but unfortunately acephalous, sphinx, the pieces of whose head were found round about, with the cartouche of a king of the 18th dynasty, was discovered not far from the others. There was also a head of Serapis in white marble, the back part and hairs of which had probably been added in plaster, and on it there are still traces of gilding and polychrome. Much more beautiful, however, is the head of a goddess, probably an Aphrodite, also in white marble and with traces. of polychrome.

Excavations were also conducted by Almas Sabry Pasha, chief eunuch of the Khedivial Palace, under the direction of Breccia Bey, who expresses his thanks to Sabry Pasha for having handed over all his discoveries of value to the Museum.

THE WESTERN NECROPOLIS. In his report Breccia Bey bemoans the apparently complete disappearance of the Western Necropolis, the underground Alexandria of Arabic legend. His efforts to arrest the destruction of this relic of bygone days were fruitless, and the exigencies of modern life, which necessitated blasting. operations, have definitely effaced the traces of the old life in which lay hidden so much precious information.

MONKS OF ALEXANDRIA. In 1903 and 1904 the Museum made two purchases of 14 funerary inscriptions refering to monks, and being supposed to have come from Dekhela. (Lefebvre- "Epitaphes de Moines Alexandrins"). Breccia Bey has devoted much attention to the discovery of the exact place from which these came and he is now certain that they were discovered in the quarries which Mr. Almagia is exploiting near the village of Dekhela, some hundred metres south of Manazer station. In this district they have found several interesting pieces of Christian architecture, a fragment of an inscription, and a large series of small calcarean Sphinxes.

OTHER DISCOVERIES. Among the ancient hills around Alexandria a fine series of vases and enamelled earthenware statuettes of the Ptolemaic and Roman periods, fragments of polychromic glass, and a series of Christian lamps of various shapes and symbols have been brought to light. An acephalous statue of the priestess Isis in white marble was discovered in the ditches of the fortifications on the west of Porte Rosette, not far from where was discovered the year before the group of Dionysos with Faune, as well as pieces of two other statues. The parts of this group which have been recently discovered resemble still more the group of Dionysos with Faune at the Chiaramonti Museum at the vatican, and it is evident that this monument must be a defective work of the Roman period. In the works carried on between the garden of the Government hospital and the Jewish cemetery, to about five metres of the actual bed of the street, ruins of either honses or perhaps annexes to a public building have been discovered. A piece of mosaic in small polychromic pebbles, representing a warrior in profile from the right side, the face turned to the left, carrying a shield on his left arm and a lance in his right hand, has been recovered. He is represented in the act of throwing a lance as he runs away and the figure occupies the centre of the mosaic with a framing of gryphons surrounded by a floral decoration, which is in a very bad state of preservation. Foundations of the house giving upon the same street have been taken out and have yielded a splendid capital in calcareous nummolithic in Corinthian style, which must have crowned a large fluted semicolumn. Some hundred metres nearer the sea in the foundations of the Maison Sursock five fragments of fluted Doric columns in red Assouan granite with a diameter of about 80 centimetres were found, the length of some of which can be estimated at five metres.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Prince Mohammed Ali Pasha Halim has gone to Geneva with his family. The Prince, who intends to pass a part of the season on the banks of lake Lehman, paid a visit to the Khedive.

Sir Vincent Corbett has sent in his resignation as Financial Adviser to the Egyptian Government. The officials, whose names are mentioned as likely successors to Sir Vincent Corbett in the Financial Advisership are Chitty Bey, Lord Edward Cecil and Mr. Farnall.
Mr. Scotidis, Hellenic Consul General, is leaving for Athens on next Wednesday by the Khedivial Mail steamer.

Neghib Bey, son of Boutros Pasha Ghali, was married on Thursday last at Constantinople to Miss Aslamian daughter of Kevork Effendi Aslamian, Assistant Director of the Ottoman Bridges and Roads Department.

Dr. W. M. Aders, who spent several years in Egypt, has just arrived from Morocco, where he has spent some months in Fez. Dr. Aders is leaving shortly for the Continent and will afterwards return to Tangier.

The burial of Mr. George Dahan took place yesterday at Alexandria, the mortal remains having arrived at Alexandria in the morning by the Messageries Maritimes steamer. The Greek Catholic Patriarch came from Cairo to conduct the funeral ceremony.
Three months' sick leave has been granted to Major V. Henry, commanding the Mounted Infantry in Egypt, dating from the 6th prox.
Captain P. R. Napier, A. S. C., has been granted sick leave from 6th prox. to February 5, 1908.
Captain W. H. V. Darell, Coldstream Guards, has returned from leave and resumed duty.

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE
div.p: La Délégation Municipale s'est réunie hier après-midi, sous la présidence de Schiess Pacha.

Sur la demande du service du nettoiement après rapport de l'ingénieur en chef, la Délé gation proposera à la Commission l'ouverture d'un crédit de 300 livres pour l'achat de quatre nouvelles voitures d'arrosage système Helmers, celle que la Municipalité possède déjà, de ce même système, ayant donné d'excellents résul tats. Elle se réserve d'acheter, l'année prochaine, six autres de ces voitures, pour en avoir dix en tout, ainsi qu'une voiture électrique d'arrosage qui passerait sur les rails de la Société des tramways, après entente avec cette Société.
-La Délégation a décidé de recommander aux services un arrosage des rues beaucoup plus abondant, particulièrement dans cette pé riode d'été.

Sur la proposition de l'inspecteur sanitaire, vu le mauvais état des échèches installées sur le terrain de Hassan Bey Abdallah, & Kom el Chongafa, la Délégation a décidé de faire prendre un arrêté prescrivant leur fermeture.

La Délégation a renvoyé à l'examen des services techniques et sanitaires les projet et plans que le Ministère a bien voulu lui faire parvenir, pour la construction de l'Hôpital pour les filles publiques et les maladies infee tieuses, construction qui sera à la charge de la Municipalité.

Le Ministère a informé la Municipalité qu'il suspend, en vue de l'examen par les services intéressés, le projet d'arrêté, pris par la Commission Municipale dans sa dernière séance, pour l'aggravation de pénalité en cas d'infraction aux dispositions des règlements de l'abattoir et des boucheries.

-La Délégation a pris connaissance des propositions des services pour l'allocation d'un emplacement sis à Gheit el Anab où seront transportées les immondices de la ville. Elle a émis un avis favorable à cet emplacement et avis chargé les services de continuer les négocia tions avec les propriétaires et a décidé en même temps de demander à la Commission l'ouverture d'une route conduisant à cet emplacement.

-La Société internationale contre la traite des blanches, ayant écrit une lettre à la Mu nicipalité, lui signalant les scandales qui se produisent dans les parcs de la rue d'Allema gne, par la présence de nombreux vagabonds et désœuvrés tant indigènes qu'européenshi molestent les bonnes qui font promener les enfants, la Délégation approuve le bien-fonde de cette lettre et décide de prendre les mesures nécessaires pour faire cesser cet inconvénient. pour faire Elle a décidé, pour le moment de placer des agents de la Police dépendant de la Municipa lité, dans ces jardins, de 9 heures à 17 du matin et de 4 à 7 heures p.m. pour 617 hebres cher que l'ordre ne soit troublé, en se réser vant, d'autre part si cette mesure n'était pas suffisante, de voir s'il ne serait pas nécessaire d'entourer ces jardins publics d'une grille en 5 fer, comme le jardin de l'Eglise Sainte Catherine.

div.head: IRISH CONSTABULARY STRIKE.
div.p: In view of the continuance of the Constabulary strike the 1st Cameron Highlanders have arrived here with a maxim gun. Sections of the 4th Middlesex and 11th Hussars are expected. The dock labourers continue to overturn vans. The Constabulary have resumed duty but are receiving many messages of sympathy from comrades elsewhere in Ireland. (Reuter)

div.head: THE HAGUE CONFERENCE.
div.p: Great Britain and Germany have agreed to a compromise regarding the Prize Court. A permanent court will be established composed of 15 judges. Each Great Power will appoint one and the rest of the world the remainder. The belligerent concerned and the appelant state will appoint assessors when the case has been tried.

M. Nelidoff has laid the foundation stone of the Carnegie Palace of Peace. The ceremony was a brilliant one. Speeches were made emphasing the almost sacred character of the building enshrining the principle of peace by right and justice. (Reuter)

div.head: THE NEW YORK FIRE.
div.p: It is believed that yesterday's tenement fire and other recent fires here are acts of incendia-
15 Italians have been killed owing to a fire in a six-storey tenement house here. (Reuter)

div.head: CRUELTIES IN THE CONGO.
div.p: HOUSE OF LORDS.-Lord Monkswell urged intervention in view of the continuance of cruelties in the Congo. Lord Fitzmaurice admitted the facts and dwelt upon the international difficulties attending intervention. There has been, he said, a careful enquiry into our judicial position but I must again appeal for delay in view of the impending bill in the Belgian Parliament. (Reuter)

div.head: MILITARY AIRSHIP
div.p: The military airship manoeuvred for two hours over the city yesterday. It followed the course of the streets, described a circle, square, parallelogram, and triangle, and returned to the suburb of Tegel. It travelled at the rate of 123 miles an hour against wind. (Reuter)

div.head: RAISULI AND MACLEAN.
div.p: El Raisuli's spies are spreading reports that Sir H. Maclean's life will be endangered if the Sultan's troops advance further. The statements are regarded as bluff.

div.head: THE KOREAN SITUATION.
div.p: Japanese troops now fully garrison the

div.head: FRENCH ELECTIONS.
div.p: The Departmental elections show consider able Progressist, Reactionary, and Nationalist losses and Republican gains, especially Radicals. The Socialists are almost stationery. Viticultural departments practically boycotted the elections.

div.head: EMPEROR AND TSAR.
div.p: The Tsar will sail for Swinemunde on Thursday, accompanied by M. Isvolsky. The details of his movements are secret but he is expected to meet the Emperor William. (R.)

div.head: GOODWOOD STEWARDS CUP.
div.p: Goodwood Stewards Cup. 1. Romney; 2. Reckless; 3. Billidere.
15 ran. Won by a head. Two lengths between second and third.
Betting 10 to 1 Romney; 6 to 1 Reckless; 20 to 1 Billidere.

div.head: COTTON V. WOOL.
div.p: The position of consumers may be stated thus: "We must have raw material, but we must have it at a price, and if we cannot have wool which we and our customers prefer at that price, then we must have cotton. We have now to compete with the whole world, and particularly with German, Belgian, French, and American manufacturers, who have as good and as efficient machinery as we have. We have some natural advantages; but we have also economic disadvantages which largely equalize the position, and we must have cheap wool to maintain our trade and to meet competition." For the present that claim has been established, and there is every indication that it will be maintained to a greater or less extent for a considerable period, or till some more powerful factor comes into play. As a matter of fact the strength of the manufacturing position. for cheap wool is exceptionally great. It seems. as if the fixed price for enormous quantities of many classes of manufactured goods and fabrics has brought into active force or into. prominence an important principle. Once a low price has been fixed and brought into ex tensive operation it is almost impossible to revoke it, at all events so long as there is a raw material either by itself or in combination with others out of which the goods can be manufactured at the given low rates.

That seems to be the fundamental principle. which in actual operation has brought about the enormous displacement of wool by cotton and the bending of the two raw materials on a very big scale. Cheap wool it is recognized will bring about a great increase in the consumption, but it has to be remembered that even at the lower rates now in force the best growths of home-grown wool are still 75 to 100 per cent. dearer than they were about five years ago. And yet in many branches of the woollen industry manufacturers are still face to face with the demand for fabrics at almost exactly the same wholesale and retail rates which prevailed when wool was practically at half its present value. On the other hand, it is true that the demand for almost all classes of goods. has greatly revived, and the Colonial trade has shown a great expansion. These changes have not, however, diminished the overwhelming demand for cheap fabrics, which have become an enormous proportion of the business done. Hence these changes, which on the face of them might seem to give a hardening tendency to raw material, in reality accentuate. the necessity for a low range of prices First. came very cheap all wool yarns and fabrics. Then, as the trade grew by leaps and bounds. and the price of wool advanced, the demand for cheap yarns and fabrics remained, and even extended. As the price limit was fixed, producers had to bring more cotton into use until the original woollen yarns became composed of half wool and half cotton, and frequently a good deal more. In fact, the fabrics in many cases have a mere facing or veneer of wool to give a soft and warm effect to the cotton. It is, of course, difficult to say whether this is the only factor which has brought about the present great decline in the price of homegrown. wool at a time of large consumption and very moderate supplies, but at all events it has played a very important part.

div.head: FOREIGNERS IN EGYPT.
div.p: In a former issue we gave a short notice of an important new work on the subject of the Capitulations, entitled "The Law affecting foreigners in Egypt as a result of the Capitulations with an account of their origin and development." The work of Mr. J. H. Scott deserves careful perusal by all interested in the solution of one of the important problems. now facing Egypt. We need not deal with the subject at length for we recently publish- ed a number of articles on this subject at the time of the publication of Lord Cromer's report and our views coincide with Mr. Scott's conclusions. The work is prefaced by an admirable introduction, which gives the reader so clear a view of the question that it deserves reproduction and will, we hope, induce our readers to make a closer acquaintance with this admirable work. Mr. Scott's, introduction to his book is in fact a succinct exposition of the outlines of the case. He writes :--

The interest which is at present centred in Egypt would, under normal circumstances, justify the discussion of the early history and development of the Capitulations; but since the publication of Lord Cromer's proposals for the modification of the system of justice. and legislation, at present in force in reference to foreigners resident in Egypt, the subject has assumed an enhanced importance. Readers of Lord Milner's "England in Egypt" are already familiar with the system of paradox which prevails in Egypt; but, even among the resident Europeans, there are few who fully understand the extent of complication which exists in the Egyptian legislative and judicial systems, at least in so far as they affect foreigners. This system has now become so complicated that it threatens to prevent useful legislation, and already, too frequently, ends in a denial of justice The system is a product of the Capitulations. This being generally admitted, it is frequently asked, "Why, then, are the Capitulations not abolished?" They are not abolished because they contain certain valuable privileges which alone make it possible. for Europeans to live in security within the territories of Egypt. Abuses, which may be traced directly to the Capitulations, undoubt edly exist, but they also contain certain pri- vileges. It would be madness for the foreigners. "to abandon their existing privileges without any adequate safeguards being provided to obviate a recurrence of these evils, which the Capitulations are intended to prevent." Abolition is out of the question, but modification would be alike beneficial to the indigenous population and the foreigner resident in Egypt. When we have traced the origin and development of the Capitulations we shall be better able to describe the present legal position of foreigners, which exists as a result of these Capitulations, and also to consider in what way this system may be modified.

The rights, privileges, and immunities which are implied in the word "Capitulation" have. changed considerably since the term was first used. The earliest Capitulations were grants of special privileges extended to foregn merchants while trading within the territories. of the grantor. At a time when Private International Law did not exist, and when not only was the foreign law unknown, but the law of each State took no account of foreigners, who themselves were distrusted, and whose entrance. was discouraged, a system such as this was essential if a permanent commerce were to be established, especially in the Eastern States of the Mediterranean. The word Capitulation. is derived from the Latin "Caput" or "Capitulum," and its origin is due to the style of the earlier grants, which were divided into heads" or articles. The grantor did not "capitulate in the modern sense, although the inferior legal status of the States which are at present regulated by Capitulations has encouraged this belief. In the original Capitulations the grantor declares, in grandiloquent terms, the importance of his position; it is the grantee who "prays, "or" begs," or "complains," and the grantor who of his "humanitie and gracious ingraffed disposition" promises redress. Nor were these privileges to be obtained without a price there is an anecdote which well illustrates the position. A certain ambassador had long sought the renewal of the privileges formerly accorded to his Sovereign. He was at length permitted to enter the presence of the Sultan's Grand Vizier, who sat near an open window, a parchment. lying on the table at his side Again and again. the wind swept the parchment away, till at length the Grand Vizier placed his perse on it, and called the attention of the ambassador to how easily the parchment, which contained the privileges desired was swept away with each gust of wind, until it was properly weighted. The presents brought by the ambassadors were not the least important part of the negotiations. But, even when properly weighted, these Capitulations were only valid during the lifetime of the grantor, and had to be renewed by his successor; and it was to these repeated renewals that the most important extensions. in the privileges originally granted were mainly due.

The privileges accorded by the early Capitulations were such as were necessary to commerce, and as such undoubtedly were as beneficial to the subjects of the grantor as to the merchants of the grantee, since without them commerce would have been impossible. They were granted by the rulers of Christian States as well as by Mohammedan princes. The earliest Capitulations, which we shall discuss, were granted by the Christian Kings of Jerusalem to the merchants of the Italian Republics of Venice, Genoa and Pisa. The system of justice and taxation practised in the in the Kingdom of Jerusalem, under the Crusaders, was based on the Feudal system, which was entirely foreign to the habits of the Italian merchants; they therefore begged and obtained the right to be exempt from taxation, except the payment of customs dues, and to be allowed to be judged by their own judges, administering their their own law. All this was granted right to live in them, as well as t special quarters of the Syrian towns. The same privileges were accorded by the Christian rulers of Cyprus and Constantinople, and in each case continued until the Mohammedan conquest. In Egypt under the Fatimites commerce revived about the eleventh century. It had always been favourably situated on the main route to the East, and under the Romans the through trade in spices had added greatly to the revenues of the country. After the Arab conquest in 641, and for many years thereafter, this commerce disappeared. The Mahommedan Law did not encourage more than a very transient truce with the unbeliever; but commercial necessity prevailed so far as to allow temporary passports to be granted to individual unbelievers trading within the territory of Islam. More than this was required before the old trade with Egypt, and through Egypt to the Far East, could be revived; and this extension was obtained by the adoption of the Capitulation system by the Moslem rulers of Egypt Once adopted, the practice spread to other Moslem States Asia Minor and Syria; to Tripoli, Tunis, Algiers and Morocco. On the conquest of Constantinople by Mohammed II. the former Capitulations granted by the Greek Emperors to Venetians and Gencese were renewed, and the system inaugurated by Christians was continued by the Mohammedans So far there had been no change in the essential part of, the Capitulations. The privileges or immunities granted by all were practically the same: permission for merchants to enter the grantor's territory and trade there; freedom to exercise their own religion, without any vexatious. regulations as to dress; the grant of a special quarter in which to live and carry on their trade; freedom from all taxes except customs. dues; immunity to some extent from local jurisdiction, and the privilege of being tried by their own consuls according to their own. law; and, lastly, the right to have their successions regulated by their own rules of inheritance. These rights formed the ground. work of all the earlier Capitulations; but beside these were a number of special grants, such as permission to build a church or a bath, or the promise to redress some special griev ance, generally the oppression of the customhouse officials. With the Moslem Capitulations of Constantinople came a change, and we may divide the remaining history of the Ottoman Capitulations into two periods.

The first of these periods commences with the first French Capitulation of 1535 and continues to the commencement of the nineteenth century. During this period the Capitulations cease to be purely commercial grants of privileges essential to merchants trading in a foreign country, and become political. Political in its inception, the Capitulation of 1535 contained a clause which was the cause of much political intrigue in the future. The offending clause was in the nature of a concession to the Pope and the Kings of England and Scotland, by which they might benefit by the privileges granted to France. From this there shortly grew the claim of France to "protect" all foreign merchants. within the Ottoman Empire a claim which was only defeated by the grant of Capitulations. to all the other important European Powers; but in the diplomatic warfare which was waged around each new grant - a warfare which was continuous owing to the necessity of constant renewal on the accession of each new Sultan - the original privileges of the Capitulations were extended beyond what was essential to commerce. And during the same period, and before the first French claim had been defeated, France put forward the claim. to protect the Christians within the Ottoman Empire a claim which led to the Crimean War. During the nineteenth century, the second of these periods, the intervention ini- tiated by France, under her claim to protect Christians, was imitated by other European Powers, and the Capitulations underwent yet another development. Commercial Conventions were entered into between the Porte and European Powers, thus separating what was purely commercial in the Capitulations from the other rights and immunities. At the same time these other rights and immunities. were confirmed for all time by being embodied in bi-lateral Treaties Nor did development stop there, since Mixed Courts were introduced administering codes based on European systems, while, at the same time, the whole Turkish administration was too hurriedly remodelled on the lines of a European State. Already, at the Conference before the Treaty of Paris, there was a demand, put forward by the Ottoman representative, for the abolition of the Capitulations.

During the nineteenth century Egypt once more regained a position of practical independence from Turkey-a state of affairs. which was recognised by the Sultan in the Firman of 1841 appointing Mohamed Aly hereditary Pasha of Egypt. These events mark the commencement of yet another stage in the development of the Capitulations. Extended as these privileges had been by the Sultans, they were destined to receive yet further extensions at the hands of Mohamed Aly and his successors in their attempt to purchase the favour of Europe. To such extremes did these rulers go that in 1867 Nubar Pasha, Ismail's Prime Minister, commenced his crusade against what he called the "Judicial Babel," which had been the result of the too lavish encouragement of European pretensions. The result was the institution of the Mixed Courts of Egypt in 1876-a reform which was almost more in the interests of foreigners than natives, to such evils did the undue extension of the Capitulations give rise. With the British Oc cupation a new era opened for Egypt-an era of judicious reform followed by the most unprecedented success; but now it is once more felt that a judicious modification of the Capitulations is again necessary, if reform and development are to be continued in the future. as they have been in the last twenty-four years. Modification, not abolition, of the Capi- tulations is necessary. The original Capitulations were as beneficial to the native subjects. as they were to the foreign merchants. Although abuses of privileges now occur, and although certain of the original privileges have ceased to be beneficial, there are yet certain very important rights guaranteed by the Capitulations--rights which are essential to the con- tinued residence of Europeans in Egypt-and "the well-being of the numerous Europeans who have made Egypt their place of residence. is indissolubly bound up with the well-being and prosperity of the country. I can conceive no greater calamity to the indigenons Egyptians than that the confidence of the best elements amongst the European communities in the institutions, under which they live and thrive, should be seriously shaken" The continuance of the Capitulations in a modified form is thus as much to the advantage of the Egyptians as the Europeans.

div.head: BRITISH ENTERPRISE BEYOND THE SEAS.
div.p: A special Commissioner of the London "Daily Mail," recently paid a surprise visit to the vast Lemco and Oxo factories and cattle ranches in the River Plate. Our readers will probably know that the Lemco and Oxo Company own over a million acres of ranches, carrying some of the finest pedigree stock in the world, including a number of Hereford bulls. and heifers from His Majesty the King's farms at Windsor, but what interested us most was the account of the minute attention which is paid to detail in the manufacture of these two well-known foods. After describing the cooling and chopping of the meat, the paper goes on to say that "from the chopping machines it emerges, into porcelain-lined receptacles, whence it is fed to the extracting apparatus. Here it joins an equal weight of pure filtered water. These extracting pans are constantly agitated at a temperature determin ed by the chemist, who, with his assistants, is always at work. When completed the liquid is drawn off into tanks, where it is allowed to settle so that every atom of fat may be drawn off. When the proper consistency is reached it. is again drawn through filters into the square 100lb. tins ready to receive it, it solidifies as it cools, is then sampled, the tins are sealed up, and it is, when boxed, ready for shipment. as "Extractum Carnis," or "Lemco" - viz, Liebig's pure Extract of Beef; as, indeed, it is. It contains no ingredients not derived from the beef itself, and it will keep good for ever. It has been untouched by human hands since the large pieces were dropped upon the revolving knives. One is struck by the perfect system that pervades these vast factories-nothing is left to chance. Every utensil, from the enormous evaporators to the smallest pan, is spotlessly clean. Cleanliness is the rule everywhere, and t can be enforced much more easily here than in an ordinary kitchen.

div.head: MAKING OXO.
div.p: Oxo is made with the same scrupulous care It consists of a combination of the best meat extract and Oxo fibrine. The latter is specially prepared from selected beef, and reduced to a powder finer than the finest flour, many pounds of prime, lean beef being required to produce each pound of fibrine."

div.head: ANCIENT EGYPT.
div.p: The exhibition of antiquities from Abydos, now on view in London under the auspices of the Liverpool University, is of extreme importance, in that it touches certain schools of archæology very badly represented in museums at present. To the student of religious developments in Egypt, one of the most important periods is that of the two centuries immediately preceding and those succeeding the Christian era. It is in the popular inscriptions of the period, especially the funeral stele, that we get the common religious belief, and here are exhibited a num ber of these records. They begin with late Ptolemaic work, then Græco Roman, where the knowledge of the hieroglyphic script is growing obscure, and the symbols borrowed from the Book of the Dead forgotten. in this exhibition, says Mr. Boscawen in a re- view of the exhibition, we see practically only three divinities, Osiris, Horus, and Anubis, with occasionally Isis and Nephthys, The series end about the third century of our era, and here we get some most valnable matter. We can clearly see how the old cult of Egypt was being unconsciously prepared for Christianity, and indeed, some of the latest of these tablets, with painted scenes and Greek inscriptions, might be ta ken for early Christian art. The figures of the goddesses become guardian angels, and the nimbus is introduced. This collection alone will make the Liverpool Museum of great use to students of early Christianity.

div.head: THE WALLS OF JERICHO.
div.p: Professor Sellin's excavations on the site of the ancient city of Jericho are yielding unexpectedly rich treasures. In his last letters to the Vienna Academy of Science the professor writes that over a hundred men are digging at five different points.

One of the most interesting finds is the historical city wall, built of burnt lime bricks. It was some ten feet in thickness, rising from a stone foundation. On the western side of the city the wall was nearly forty feet in width. At another point a private house was found built over another house of a still earlier epoch.

Other discoveries include lamps, plates, cups, needles, weights, mortars, and mills of bronze and stone, some of very rough and primitive. handwork, and others very finely executed. In the inner city remains of rows of houses have been uncovered. The ancient Hebrew lettering proves that the old Hebrew characters were

Professor Sellin hopes to renew the excavating work next winter. In the meantime he says that the work already done has opened up a wealth of material for the student of the pre- Israelite ani Canaanite period.

div.head: MINERAL WATERS.
div.p: We remind our readers that Spathis' celerated minerals are the best in Egypt. [ADVT.

div.head: BUSINESS PROSPECTS IN THE SUDAN.
div.p: After considering this outline of the Government policy it is disappointing to learn that in reality no measures are taken to encourage commercial men to invest money in the country, or even to visit it. On the contrary, it is only too apparent that they are not wanted. there, and, in fact, no one other than a mili tary officer is of any real consequence. As far back as six years ago Lord Cromer drew attention to the desirability of creating a Sudan Civil Service, and in the same report Sir Reginald Wingate, the Governor-General, announced that such a service had actually been created, with the difference that the officials were military. He pointed out one serious drawback to the system, however-namely, that these officers, being on the active list or the British Army, were liable to be called away at any moment for service elsewhere, or they might tire of their arduous work and return to their own service. In short, the British officers could not be counted on as a permanency. Lord Cromer emphasized the point, and explained that some time must elapse before officers who arrive to fill vacant places could acquire the linguistic and local knowledge necessary for the efficient performance of their duties. The following year he repeated his argument that the military should be gradually replaced by the civil element in the Sudan Administration, but he deprecated any brusque change. In spite of all this advice, however, there is no evidence of any intention to substitute the civilian for the military official, and therefore nothing is being done of a practical nature to attract trade.

The men of business, whether manufacturers merchants, or shipowners, who have visited Khartoum with the view to studying schemes for trade development, have been obliged to apply for information to the military or naval officers who control those spending departments of government-with one exception-which have the ordering of everything included under the term of "government stores," and the results of their interviews with these officers have rarely been profitable or even pleasant. Most of them have complained of the difficulties of approaching the military official and of the scant courtesy with which they were received; also of the vexatious delays, caused too often through his lack of appreciation of the importance of keeping a business appointment, thereby necessitating in many instances a prolonged stay at the local hotel. (There are but two mail trains a week, and they are the only practicable means of departure.) Some allowance should be made for the fact that the military officer has not been trained to deal with business men and is not accustomed to do so. But I consider it quite impossible. to persuade him to treat them as most necessary factors in connexion with the progress of the Sudan.

Port Sudan, as the chief port of entry on the Red Sea, has been designed on an elaborate scale to meet the requirements of a large Government business, and much attention has been devoted to its equipment. A sum of £895.000 is being expended on harbour improvements and the construction of quays, Custom-house, and other Government offices, official residences, etc., but no provision has apparently been made for the real attraction of trade to the port, and therefore a great deal of this expenditure seems to be somewhat premature. In the initial stages of development of other countries it has usually been found that as soon as a trade was created shipowners. competed with one another to capture it, and they made their own arrangements for receiving or discharging cargo, with the aid of local agents. In course of time, if the expansion of trade justified the expense, the harbours were improved, and quays were built and gradually extended. In Port Sudan the old order of things has been reversed, under the belief that trade will come if only the port is made sufficiently comfortable for its accommodation. The idea was evolved, no doubt, from the Somewhat natural desire of the Sudan to enjoy the advantages of handling, and charging Customs dues upon, its own trade-in other words, to secure for itself the benefits of carrying from ship to consumer, and from producer to ship, instead of dividing such benefits with Egypt as heretofore. Unfortunately for the early success of the scheme, trade declines to be diverted into inconvenient channels for the sake of merely pleasing the ruling power, and there are many far-reaching influences connected with commerce which have apparently escaped the consideration of the Government. The following appropriate remarks were addressed by Lord Cromer (Egypt, No, 1, 1906) to the British Government a year Nowhere is the exercise of that somewhat rare quality, a sense of proportion, more necessary than in the Sudan. With every wish to progress as rapidly as possible, it has to be remembered that the work of generations cannot be compressed into a few years. The field for reform in the Sudan is indeed very wide, but the main question to be decided whether in respect to points. bearing on the material, or on the moral progress of the country-is generally not So much whether the adoption of any proposed measure is desirable as whether the 100ment has arrived for its execution, and whether, in point of relative importance, it should have precedence over other proposals.

The creation of Port-Sudan resembles that of several ports of German colonies in Africa, where splendid quays, warehouses, and cus toms offices were constructed and overstaffed with numbers of unitormed officials. Military despotism holds its sway, and civilian residents are kept in strict order. But there is no trade; the main reason being that there are no experienced pioneers to organize it; and trade is not of spontaneous growth. Capable merchants avoid such places like the plague, and the German trader is the last man in the world to settle in his own colony.

The entire foreshore of Port Sudan is reserved for the use of various Government departments. Trade is relegated far away into the background. The post and telegraph offices, governor's offices, police offices, barracks, official residences, and the convient prison are being built on the sea frontage. Shipping offices, mercantile offices, warehouses, repairing shops, and the like, if ever desired, may be erected far in the rear, on land set apart for the purpose, as distant as possible from the post and telegraph offices, the banks, public offices, and the residentlal quarter, from all of which if and when the port grows busy, will often be opened at inconvenient hours.

At Khartum a similar state of things prevails The river frontage is monopolized, for a distance of about three miles by Government offices and official residences. The general effect is picturesque, but it is neither useful nor economical. No trading of any description is permitted along this stretch of frontage, and no merchandise, unless imported by the Go- vernment, can be landed within its sacred confines. Traders' goods must be discharged at a distant point down stream, and transported, at considerable expense, around to the commercial quarter of the city.

On the opposite bank of the Nile is Khartum North, with the terminus of the railway from Halfa and Port Sudan. But here again there is no room for the merchant, because anything like reasonable access to either river of railway is debarred to him by immense ranges of Government storeyards and work- shops, and military barracks.

In short, it is an obvious and incontestable. fact that the merchant is not regarded as a desirable settler in the country; and, until that fact is removed by the reforms which are so necessary to the general welfare of the Sudan, it would be a waste of time to write of the opportunities it holds for commercial enterprise.

div.head: MACHINERY USED IN BUILDING THE PYRAMIDS,
div.p: Hoisting machines were used in both Assyria and Egypt six thousand or more years ago. In order to hoist the great stones of the Pyramids, some form of derrick was employed. Probably the first constuction was that which is now known to mechanics as the shear-legs, says Charies H. Cochrane in the "Circle" magazine. This is made of two great timbers. tied together in the form of a capital A, the two ends resting on the ground and a rope being run over and attached at the top. With one of these the pyramid builders could have raised large stones step by step, which was doubtless their method. We can imagine we see the great A frame leaning over an incline. of perhaps fifty degrees, with a block of stone. tied on. Then a great crowd of men got hold of the rope on the opposite side, perhaps assisted by some draft oxen, and all strain and pull until the A-frame stands erect and the stone is swung up into the air, where it can be pushed into the desired place. Such a contrivance could be used to lift stones six or eight feet, which was sufficient for the construction of the first pyramid. Doubtless 'better hoisting devices were constructed as more pyramids were built.
An examination will be held at the Alex-
andria Post Office at 9 a.m. on the 10th August next for the purpose of filling vacancies of apprentices on a monthly allowance at Cairo and Alexandria.

Intending candidates must be of Egyptian Nationality and at least 18 years old and must forward their applications to the Postmaster General, General Post Office, Alexandria, made out in their own handwriting on Ministerial Form No. 167 C.G. not later than the 8th August.
The following must accompany this Form: 1. Primary Education Certificate obtained within the last three years or preferably a Subordinate Service Certificate.

2. A certificate showing that the candidate has paid his military exemption fee or that he has not yet been selected for conscription. If the candidate is attached to another Government Administration, he must obtain written permission to attend the examination from his Chief and forward it together with the other documents. Alexandria, July 30th 1907.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Second Lieutenant L. D. St. Salusbury Trelawney, King's Royal Rifle Corps, on first appointment, has been posted to the 1st Battalion, at Khartoum, and will accompany the draft which will be despatched in September to that battalion.

Lieutenant Arthur D. H. Britton, Royal Dublin Fusiliers, has just severed his connection with that regiment, with which he had been associated for eight years. He served with the West African Frontier Force in the Borgu Expedition, 1897-98 (medal with clasp), and with the gallant "Dubs" in South Africa from the time Colenso was fought and Ladysmith relieved, to the close of the operations in the Transvaal (mentioned in despatches, Queen's medal with four clasps, King's medal with two clasps).

This year is likley to prove a phenomenal one in gunnery throughout the British Navy. The Mediterranean fleet, and the home fleets have done exceptionally well, and the "King Alfred," flagship of the China Station, recently established a record which will take some beating-188 hits out of 198 rounds, and 113 of them bullseyes.

"Is the short rifle a failure" is a question that many have recently asked. It is stated that it is doubtful if any more of that particular pattern be issued, and that the long Lee Enfield, with the short rifle sights, will be the rifle of the future.

Several cases have occurred recently in which non-commissioned officers on reduction to the ranks, have been sent home from abroad for premature transfer to the Reserve, but have not had the conditions. upon which the transfer was made explained to them, as required by regulation. It has therefore been notified that in the case of soldiers in the receipt of service pay he is to be warned that, unless he has drawn such pay wholly in virtue of his rank, or appointment, as a non-commissioned officer, he will be required to pay £10, under Artiele 1288 c. of the Pay Warrant, as a condition of his Reserve, before the normal expiration of his service with the colours. This payment will not be insisted on in cases where service pay has been drawn as a private for the short period between reduction and transfer, provided such pay is refunded.

A strong effort is about to made to grapple with the typhoid fever so prevalent in tropical garrisons. Captain S. de C. O'Grady, Royal Army Medical Corps, who is a specialist in typhoid and kindred diseases, has been specially selected to accompany the 1st Battalion of the Green Howards to Egypt, where he will remain with it for its three years tour for the purpose of carrying out anti-typhoid treatment amongst volunteers, and to watch the general health of the battailon. Lieutenant G. H. Stevenson, and Lieutenant J. B. G. Mulligan, Royal Army Medical Corps, have been similarly selected to accompany the 1st King's Dragoon Guards, and the 1st Battalion Suffolk Regiment to India and Malta respectively.

The Army Council has circulated for consideration by Generals Commanding-in-Chief a memorandum relative to a scheme to which it is proposed to substitute a cash allowance for soldiers in place of the existing system of issues of clothing or of compensation in lieu of clothing. The proposal, which is the result of consideration of many alternative schemes is that the recruit shall continue to receive a complete outfit on enlistment as a present; but that, from the beginning of his second year of service he shall be paid in additiou to a sum equal to 2d per day for "upkeep of kit," a quarterly clothing allowance, and that from then on all clothing transactions between him and the State shall be on a cash basis, articles, being purchased as necessaries are now, Serving soldiers have more than fifteen months to serve would be brought under the new rules. In addition to the direct benefit to the soldier, the new scheme will be of great advantage to company commanders, quartermasters, and accountants, in avoiding the numerous queries on accounts and disallowances occurring under the present intricate. system which are the causes of voluminious correspondence and inevitably result in dissatisfaction.

The following is being substituted for the present syllabus for the subjects of "Military History and Strategy (Obligatory)" in the entrance examination for the Staff College, and will come into force in the examination to be held in August next:-The general principles of strategy in civilized warfare. The special principles illustrated by the following compaigns:- 1815, in Belguim, 1862, in Virginia, to the second battle of Bull Run, inclusive 1866, in Bohemia, to the battle of Koniggatz, inclusive, the Russo-Japanese War, 1905, to the battle of Liao, Yang inclusive."

It has been announced in home command orders that His Excellency the Commander in Chief in India, has decided that in future the names of candidates for service with the Mountain Batteries of India who do not come up for appointment by the time that they are within the first hundred for promotion to captain, will be removed from the lists, and in view of this decision, the names of subalterns who are within the first 150 will not be regis tered in the future. Exception to this rule will only be made in the case of candidates who possess exceptional qualifications, and where there is a reasonable prospect of employment before they come within the specified limit.

div.head: CAUGHT BY THE GRIP-.
div.p: HE disease now known as 'grip' used to be called 'influenza.'
It very closely resembles a cold, but is more tenacious in its hold upon the system and produces more profound disturbances.
Grip is in reality epidemic catarrh. When it once begins it spreads over the country very rapidly.
People do not catch the grip from each other, but each one catches it from the atmosphere.
"Most Effective Medicine Ever Tried for La Crippe."
Robt. L. Madison, A. M., Principal of Cullowhee High School, Painter, N. C., is chairman of the Jackson County Board of Education.
He is a writer of occasional verse and has contributed to a number of leading papers and magazines,-religious, educational and secular.
In speaking of Peruna, Mr. Madison says:
"I am hardly ever without Peruna in my home. It is the most effective medi- cine that I have ever tried for la grippe.
"It also cured my wife of nasal catarrh. Her condition at one time was such that she could not at night breathe through her nostrils.
"In consequence, an inflamed condition of the throat was brought about, getting worse and worse and yielding to no remedy until Peruna was tried."
Healthy Mucous Membranes. Those who are fortunate enough to have perfectly healthy mucous membranes ordinarily do not catch the grip.
The mucous membranes lining the nose, throat and lungs, when in a normal state, are an effectual barrier against the invasion of grip.
But, if there happens to be the slightest catarrhal derangement of the mucous membranes, then the victim becomes an easier prey to the grip.
This in part explains why some people get the grip, while others do not.

The rational thing to do is to keep the system free from catarrh. In attempt- ing to do this most people have found Perans to be invaluable. Systemic Catarrh, the Result of La Grippe. Pe-ru-na Receives Credit
for Present Good Health. Mrs. Jennie W. Gilmore, Box 44, White Oak, Ind. Ter., formerly Housekeeper for Indiana Reform School for Boys, writes:
"Six years ago I had la grippe, which was followed by systemic catarrh.
"The only thing I used was Peruna and Manalin, and I have been in better Health the last three years than for years before.
"I give Pertina'all the credit for my good health."
The Medical Profession Recognizes The Grip as Epidemic Catarrh.
During an epidemic of grip Peruna should be used. The doses recommended on the bottle are sufficient.
After the grip has once been acquired, Dr. Hartman recommends the use of Peruna in teaspoonful doses every hour during the acute stage, after which the directions on the bottle should be followed.
Experience has shown that the people who use Peruna as a remedy for grip generally recover sooner and are less liable to the distressing and long-continued after-effects of the grip.
"Two years ago I began using Peruna and it built up my strength so that in a couple of months I was able to go to work again.
"This winter I had another attack of la grippe, but Peruna soon drove it out of my system. My wife and I consider Peruna a household remedy."
Pneumonia Eollowed La Grippe. Mr. T Barnecott, West Aylmer, Ontario, Can., writes:

"Last winter I was ill with pneumonia after having la grippe. I took Peruna for two months, when I became When Peruna has not been used durquite well, and I can say that any one ing the course of the grip and the patient can be cured by it in a reasonable time finds himself suffering from the afterat little expense." effects of this disease, a course of Peruna Pe-ru-na-A Tonic After La Grippe. should be resorted to. Mrs. Chas. E. Wells, Sr., Delaware, Suffered Twelve Years From After-Ohio, writes: "After a severe attack of la grippe, I took Peruna and found it very good tonic."
Mr. Victor Patneaude, 828 Madison St., Topeka, Kan., member of Knights and Ladies of Security, writes:
"Twelve years ago I had a severe attack of la grippe and I never really re- covered my health and strength-but grew weaker every year, until I was unable to work.

Mrs. Jane Gift, Athens, Ohio, writes: "Six years ago I had la grippe very bad. I read a testimonial of a woman who had been cured of grip by Peruna. My husband bought me a bottle of Peruns. I was soon able to do my work. I continued using it until I was cured."
